head.title: The Look, and Outlook, of a Gallery

hedline.hl1: The Look, and Outlook, of a Gallery

abstract.p: Howard Goldberg reviews some Italian wines available at Rosenthal Wine Merchant, NYC; photo (M)

block.p: Although Rosenthal Wine Merchant's reputation for selectivity flows from its French portfolio, its smaller Italian collection is equally discriminating.
Will Helburn, the manager, sells wines that Neal Rosenthal, the importer, finds at small estates. The wines echo local grapes and vineyard specifics.
Although Rosenthal Wine Merchant's reputation for selectivity flows from its French portfolio, its smaller Italian collection is equally discriminating.
Will Helburn, the manager, sells wines that Neal Rosenthal, the importer, finds at small estates. The wines echo local grapes and vineyard specifics.

The clubby shop, which relies more heavily on phone sales than walk-ins, thus thrives on individualism. The art crowd, making the Upper East Side circuit on Saturdays, might easily mistake Rosenthal, in part of a brownstone at 318 East 84th Street (Second Avenue), for a gallery. It is one, of sorts.

Unlike most wine stores, Rosenthal represents a steady-state point of view. You might not agree with, or like, every expression of that outlook, but you can appreciate why its stock of unfamiliar names is tantalizing just to see.
Take, for example, four cold weather Piedmont reds that Mr. Helburn recommends.

The young '98 Ferrando Montodo Canavese rosso ($10), a casual, easy-sipping wine for daily use, displays a tender perfume and, the longer the bottle remains open and aerating, an unfolding complexity.

The '99 De Forville Dolcetto d'Alba Vigneto Loreto ($10.50) is a young, brooding, delicious beauty. The sultry aroma and rich flavor are separate but equal treats. Overall, the wine is elegant, smooth, deep and nuanced: a striking value.

Another version of Dolcetto d'Alba, Brovia's '99 Vignavillej ($16.50), was opaque, magically fruity and tarry in aroma, voluptuous -- virtually a compote. Decanting it offered insights into prospective complexity.

Brovia's mellow '96 Valmaggione ($19), a Nebbiolo d'Alba, seemed, well, so very Italian -- the way a Gauloise cigarette's aroma can be only French -- that it takes an Italian sensibility to plumb it. Odd how a wine can make you feel like a (welcome) outsider.
Savor enough of Rosenthal's beckoning Italian reds and you become an insider.
